banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Women and girls, you are part of the climate solution
videoData.socialTitle: Women and girls, you are part of the climate solution

recommendations.blurb: More resources curated by Rumaitha Al Busaidi

recItems.blurb: A collection of essays and interviews from the leaders of environmental and feminist movements that bring to light a strong case that having gender parity is imperative for environmental progress. The book talks about how women issues interconnect with environmental issues and how we can take steps to ensure that we can pursue gender parity and climate justice in parallel.
recItems.headline: *Why Women Will Save the Planet*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Friends of the Earth
Zed Books, 2015

recItems.blurb: An interesting book written by Christiana Figueres and Tom Rivett-Carnac. They both led the climate negotiations for the UN during the historic Paris Agreement in 2015. The book talks about the scenarios that are possible for the world we live in should we not achieve the targets set out in the Paris Agreement and what it would take for us to lead a carbon neutral world.
recItems.headline: *The Future We Choose: The Stubborn Optimist's Guide to the Climate Crisis*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Christiana Figueres and Tom Rivett-Carnac
Penguin Random House, 2021

recItems.blurb: While it grew to be a phenomenon, not many people have yet watched it. This series is made up of eight episodes where each episode you discover the effects human activities have left on our natural ecosystems, but also shows you ways you can make a difference either as a person or collectively as a community.
recItems.headline: *Our Planet*
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: These videos series pretty much sums up why, as a woman, it is important to negotiate and how you can use the typical gender stereotypes in negotiations to flip things around to your advantage. If you are a male ally, these tips may help the women around you negotiate better.
recItems.headline: *Why Negotiating Is Crucial for Women*
recItems.label: WATCH
recItems.note:
Ashleigh Shelby Rosette
Duke University, Fuqua School of Business

recItems.blurb: We tend to hear that women seem to underperform men when it comes to negotiations, this new research brings to light new evidence as to why that is so and provides some tips on how to level the playing field.
recItems.headline: "Why Women Fall Short In Negotiations (It's Not Lack Of Skill)"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: The best way for millennial Arab women to become stronger negotiators and enter a male-dominated space is to develop a growth mindset. Having a growth mindset means you are always willing to learn and use any potential challenges as opportunities to grow and become a stronger person. A growth mindset can also help you build your confidence, so you can better understand your worth and be better able to negotiate on your own terms.
recItems.headline: "5 Ways Arab Millennial Women Can Develop A Growth Mindset"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

takeAction.blurb: **Help close** the confidence gap and give Arab women a resource to achieve more together.

learnModules.blurb: Learn how you can help cut the world's emissions in half by 2030, in the race to a zero-carbon world.
learnModules.headline: Countdown: A global initiative to accelerate solutions to the climate crisis

nodes.whoTheyAre: Omani scientist, activist and athlete Rumaitha Al Busaidi empowers Arab women to step into spaces previously denied to them -- whether it’s a football field, volcano summit or the front line of the battle against climate change.
nodes.whyListen: Rumaitha Al Busaidi is the founder of WomeX, a platform teaching negotiation skills to Arab women in order to nurture a new wave of female entrepreneurs in the region.

videoData.description: What does gender equality have to do with climate change? A lot more than you might think. Empowering women and girls around the world is one of the most important ways to combat carbon pollution and is projected to reduce CO2-equivalent gases by a total of 80 billion tons. Entrepreneur, scientist and TED Fellow Rumaitha Al Busaidi looks at why women are more likely to be impacted and displaced by climate catastrophes -- and explains why access to education, employment and family planning for all women and girls is the key to our climate future.
videoData.socialDescription: What does gender equality have to do with climate change? A lot more than you might think. Empowering women and girls around the world is one of the most important ways to combat carbon pollution and is projected to reduce CO2-equivalent gases by a total of 80 billion tons. Entrepreneur, scientist and TED Fellow Rumaitha Al Busaidi looks at why women are more likely to be impacted and displaced by climate catastrophes -- and explains why access to education, employment and family planning for all women and girls is the key to our climate future.

cues.text:
When we think of solutions
to global warming,

we generally think in terms
of technology or policy,
but other approaches are necessary

which have to do with how
our societies are structured.
The most important of them

is educating and empowering
women and girls.
Now, don't take my word for it.

Its potential impact
has been calculated by scientists.

Like, for instance,
those working on Project Drawdown,
who focus on greenhouse gas emissions.

They calculated that educating
and empowering women and girls
is one of the single most important things

that we can do to confront
carbon pollution.

It may result in a total reduction
of CO2-equivalent gases
of over 80 billion tons,

which is not far from double
the total annual global emissions.

As a marine scientist
and nature adventurer,
I've witnessed firsthand

how climate change
impacts the world we live in.

These climate catastrophes
have almost taken my life.

Like when I was nearly buried alive
during an avalanche
or swept away by a cyclone.
Thankfully, I survived,

but will our grandchildren
call this planet home in 2050 or 2100
if our trajectory continues?
Coming from a male-dominated society,

I've been asked all sorts
of intrusive questions
as to why I do what I do.
"Can you even travel alone?"

"Are you capable of climbing mountains
with your heavier figure?
I mean, are you fit enough?"

"Do you think, as a woman,
you're equipped to do this?"
And the answer has always been, yes.

I want to show my fellow Arab women
that anything is possible,

that being a woman should not be
the end to your dreams,

that you are so much more
than what you are conditioned to be,

and that you are indeed the solution
to the crisis facing our planet.

In 2020, women made up about 40 percent
of the global workforce.

Women's shares in the Middle East
are just under 25 percent.

And these figures are way lower
in the Gulf countries.

And considering that women
make up nearly half of the Gulf,

imagine how women's equal
involvement in the economy

could enhance the overall
growth of the region.
Many labor laws state

that there's no discrimination
between men and women.

Yet women's upward mobility
is quite restricted

and many senior positions
are still being held by men.

The cultural perception
that women are more emotional

or better suited
to household responsibilities

remains a serious obstacle
for ambitious women
who end up underemployed.

So what does that have to do
with the climate?

Well, access to education,
employment and family planning

is the condition for more vibrant lives
for women and girls,

for their families
and their entire communities.
They get to earn more money,

achieve career goals
and face fewer health issues.

And not only that,
they become more resilient

and better equipped to manage
both food and nature

and to cope with the impacts
of climate change.
Women are also the ones most at risk

when it comes to impacts
of climate catastrophes like cyclones,

which have grown more frequent
in my own home country of Oman.
And why?

Well because they're left with a charge
of the children or elderly,
they don't know how to swim,

or simply because they never had
basic resilience skills taught to them,
like building a shelter, making a fire
or even administering basic first aid.
In fact, UN figures indicate

that 80 percent of people
displaced by climate change
are women.

And with more of these
occurrences happening,
my gender will face more of the brunt

further preventing them
from achieving their potential
and protecting themselves.
This is why I founded WomeX,

a platform where we teach women
from my community negotiation skills

to nurture a new wave
of girl bosses in the region.

WomeX is on a mission
to laying the groundwork
to combating climate change

by bridging localized context
and leadership training.
By educating more women on these skills,
we hope to equip them with the tools

that allow them to control
their careers and their lives,

and to contribute significantly
to the collective efforts
necessary to confront carbon pollution.
So far, we've supported a thousand

and are working hard to achieve
our ambitious goal of a million.
Now, even though it has been

on the global sustainability
radar for years,
gender parity as a climate solution

has not received
the attention it deserves.
Now is the time to make it a priority.

Now is the time to educate
and empower all women and all girls.
Thank you.
